lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">LESS lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">THAN ten minutes into “lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Alternate lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Endings: lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Six lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ways to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Die in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America”, a brief conversation between lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The widow and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The sister of a man who is about to have an unconventional lass="word-wrap-span">funeral highlights just how much attitudes to death, dying and grieving are starting to change in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The sister begins by saying that she and her brolass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Thers used to hate going to lass="word-wrap-span">funerals; lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They were allass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ways big old-fashioned affairs on a Sunday in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The family plot in a Brooklyn lass="word-wrap-span">cemetery. “We just didn’t like it,” she says. “So this is a very different lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Way to honour somebody. It’s a very good thing to do.”

“lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Absolutely,” answers lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The widow. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then, speaking of her daughter lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Leila, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">She adds, “it’s going to be very good for her. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">She hasn’t had time to lass="word-wrap-span">grieve.” lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The “different way” lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They are honouring lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their dead is by placing his alass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Shes in a “memorial reef” lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And planting it at lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The bottom of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The seabed. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">lass="word-wrap-span">cremated remains are mixed with lass="word-wrap-span">cement, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then placed inside a man-made reef in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Gulf of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Mexico. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The last shot of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The segment is of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Leila cradling lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The memorial underwater, her face obscured by lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The deep-sea lass="word-wrap-span">diving equipment, her arms hugging it close.

It is one of many quietly moving moments in this lass="word-wrap-span">documentary from lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">HBO, which takes a subject most people are wary of thinking of, are keen to avoid—death—and looks at it straight on. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The starting point of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The film is that, in 2018, lass="word-wrap-span">cremations overtook ordinary, mostly very expensive lass="word-wrap-span">burials in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Increasingly people want to have more control over how or when lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They die; or, once lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They are dead, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their relatives want to lass="word-wrap-span">celebrate lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their lives in ways that do not lass="word-wrap-span">conform to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The notion of a traditional lass="word-wrap-span">funeral.

Guadelupe (pictured), a terminally-ill man, has a “living wake” with all his family and friends surrounding him several months before he dies. Barbara lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Jean, who has pancreatic cancer, goes with her best friend TJ to see the “green lass="word-wrap-span">burial” (ie, lass="word-wrap-span">environmentally friendly) plot where she will be laid. As they view the site in a golf lass="word-wrap-span">buggy, the woman who works at the lass="word-wrap-span">burial ground tells her that people, when viewing their prospective plots, tend to lie on the ground and look up at the sky, to take in their lass="word-wrap-span">burial view. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Soon after, the film shows TJ and Barbara’s other friends washing her body and interring her at the spot she has chosen, planting a tree in the grave at the same time.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The film also follows families who send lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">cremations of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their loved ones into space on a rocket. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Emily and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ryan lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Matthias, a couple whose five-year-old son lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Garrett died of cancer, are interviewed too: he asked for lass="word-wrap-span">bouncy lass="word-wrap-span">castles and superheroes to be at his “life lass="word-wrap-span">celebration”, ralass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther than having a “sad” lass="word-wrap-span">funeral, so after his death lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They followed through with his wishes.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The most striking lass="word-wrap-span">episode in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The hour-long lass="word-wrap-span">documentary, however, is lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The segment following lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Shannon, a former lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Silicon lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Valley engineer whose cancer has stubbornly remained despite treatment, and has now metastasised into his lungs. He wants to end his life on his own terms, and lives in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">California, a state lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With a “death lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With lass="word-wrap-span">dignity” law which allows him to do so. In lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The first shot of him, he is lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With his wife of 57 years, visiting lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The doctor who runs through how he is to take lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The end-of-life medication: lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lethal cocktail needs to be prepared somewhere which is not a public place and, although it can be mixed by someone else, he has to take it lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Without lass="word-wrap-span">assistance. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Usually, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The doctor explains, people slip into a lass="word-wrap-span">coma and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Then die lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Within half an hour of taking it. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">With tears in her eyes his wife says that “it’s a really difficult process, but it lass="word-wrap-span">feels like lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The right decision”.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Afterwards, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And wife take down the end-of-life medication from the top of their closet—next to a box marked “lass="word-wrap-span">dressy clothes”—lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And go through its contents for the camera. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Later he lass="word-wrap-span">constructs his lass="word-wrap-span">casket with his son-in-law, who quips that he hopes lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick is not going to lie down in it there lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And then. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And then, six months lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Later lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When the cancer has got much worse lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And his lungs are failing, he throws a party for 40 guests. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">One friend toasts his drink with lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick’s, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">And says, “lass="word-wrap-span">cheerful checking out”. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Another asks: “No time soon I hope?” To which lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick replies: “I’m checking out Tuesday morning.” lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">When his friend looks mildly shocked, he explains further: “I want to go out with a quality of life. I can lass="word-wrap-span">feel it deteriorating. I know what’s happening. I want it to be on my terms. Tuesday morning is it.”

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The film follows lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Dick and his family as lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They have lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their “last supper” togelass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ther. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Afterwards lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They all cry listening to “Amazing lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Grace”, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">hymn which will be played at his lass="word-wrap-span">funeral. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The next day, he drinks lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The cocktail, tells his family around him that he loves lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Them, and lies back on his sofa. As he slips into lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">coma, and as his body makes its death rattle, his wife explains to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their children that it is all perfectly normal. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">This is death: a sleep from which lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There is no waking.

lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The moment is lass="word-wrap-span">incredibly moving: a man dying, on his own terms, in his own home, surrounded by his wife, children and in-laws. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The strength of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The lass="word-wrap-span">documentary, which offers little by way of lass="word-wrap-span">commentary, is that lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The camera does not lass="word-wrap-span">feel overly lass="word-wrap-span">intrusive; lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">There is no presenter providing a morbid narrative. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Instead, lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The words of lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The dying and lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">The grieving are given lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Their due space and time. lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">They deserve to be listened to.

“lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Alternate lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Endings: lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Six lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">New lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Ways to lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">Die in lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">America” is released on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">HBO on lass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">August 14th
